category_summary:
**Andrew Ng**'s [comprehensive analysis](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-1379782f1cad) of AI's real impact on the job market dominated discourse, arguing job losses are overhyped while emphasizing AI-augmented workers replacing those without AI skills. Meanwhile, **OpenAI** made multiple product moves: **Greg Brockman** [demoed **GPT-5.3-Codex**](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-6224d8d38364) for cross-language application rewriting, and Deep Research was [upgraded to **GPT-5.2**](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-1a92ba7ed13a) with new features.

- **Demis Hassabis** announced **Isomorphic Labs**' drug design engine is [extending state-of-the-art benchmarks](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-372cbdb99dec), reinforcing AI's transformative potential in healthcare
- **Ethan Mollick** [shared NBER research](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-40bed350b2df) showing LLMs tripled book releases since 2022—average quality fell but top-ranked books actually improved
- **Mollick** also revealed that **Claude Opus 4.6** quietly [introduced spontaneous subagent spawning](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-d78c5f9ad0de) in **Claude Code**, a significant capability upgrade AI labs failed to communicate clearly
- **Anthropic** [shared striking internal metrics](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-eae6ad72712f): 67% increase in PRs per developer per day, with 70-90% of code now written by **Claude**
- **Matt Shumer**'s viral article about AI's real trajectory [reached over 10M views](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-2e243097ae49), signaling growing mainstream appetite for honest AI discourse
- **Runway** [raised $315M in Series E](/?date=2026-02-11&category=social#item-47ab6a4248c7) funding to advance world models, calling them the most transformative technology of our time

items.title: Job seekers in the U.S. and many other nations face a tough environment. At the same time, fears of ...
items.content:
Job seekers in the U.S. and many other nations face a tough environment. At the same time, fears of AI-caused job loss have — so far — been overblown. However, the demand for AI skills is starting to cause shifts in the job market. I’d like to share what I’m seeing on the ground. 

First, many tech companies have laid off workers over the past year. While some CEOs cited AI as the reason — that AI is doing the work, so people are no longer needed — the reality is AI just doesn’t work that well yet. Many of the layoffs have been corrections for overhiring during the pandemic or general cost-cutting and reorganization that occasionally happened even before modern AI. Outside of a handful of roles, few layoffs have resulted from jobs being automated by AI.
Granted, this may grow in the future. People who are currently in some professions that are highly exposed to AI automation, such as call-center operators, translators, and voice actors, are likely to struggle to find jobs and/or see declining salaries. But widespread job losses have been overhyped.

Instead, a common refrain applies: AI won’t replace workers, but workers who use AI will replace workers who don’t. For instance, because AI coding tools make developers much more efficient, developers who know how to use them are increasingly in-demand. (If you want to be one of these people, please take our short courses on Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and Agentic Skills!)

So AI is leading to job losses, but in a subtle way. Some businesses are letting go of employees who are not adapting to AI and replacing them with people who are. This trend is already obvious in software development. Further, in many startups’ hiring patterns, I am seeing early signs of this type of personnel replacement in roles that traditionally are considered non-technical. Marketers, recruiters, and analysts who know how to code with AI are more productive than those who don’t, so some businesses are slowly parting ways with employees that aren’t able to adapt. I expect this will accelerate.

At the same time, when companies build new teams that are AI native, sometimes the new teams are smaller than the ones they replace. AI makes individuals more effective, and this makes it possible to shrink team sizes. For example, as AI has made building software easier, the bottleneck is shifting to deciding what to build — this is the Product Management (PM) bottleneck. A project that used to be assigned to 8 engineers and 1 PM might now be assigned to 2 engineers and 1 PM, or perhaps even to a single person with a mix of engineering and product skills.

The good news for employees is that most businesses have a lot of work to do and not enough people to do it. People with the right AI skills are often given opportunities to step up and do more, and maybe tackle the long backlog of ideas that couldn’t be executed before AI made the work go more quickly. I’m seeing many employees in many businesses step up to build new things that help their business. Opportunities abound!

I know these changes are stressful. My heart goes out to every family that has been affected by a layoff, to every job seeker struggling to find the role they want, and to the far larger number of people who are worried about their future job prospects. Fortunately, there’s still time to learn and position yourself well for where the job market is going. When it comes to AI, the vast majority of people, technical or nontechnical, are at the starting line, or they were recently. So this remains a great time to keep learning and keep building, and the opportunities for those who do are numerous!

[Original text; https://t.co/zbIhZHfCC0 ]

items.content:
Every time someone asks me what's going on with AI, I give them the safe answer. Because the real one sounds insane.

I'm done holding back.

I wrote what I wish I could sit down and tell everyone I care about.

Send it to someone who needs to read it.

The AI Labs don't yet do a good job explaining how the upgrades to their harnesses change work

For example, since Opus 4.6, Claude Code will spontaneously use subagents to do work in parallel. This is very helpful with a real impact on tasks, but was sort of quietly rolled out without documentation

items.title:
The concept of ‘business meetings’ has changed yet again. 

And it’s because of AI agents. 

Because...
items.content:
The concept of ‘business meetings’ has changed yet again. 

And it’s because of AI agents. 

Because now before every long meeting I am forced to ask myself what I want Claude Code or Claude Chrome to do for me during that time. 

Meetings used to just be humans talking for 45 minutes. 

Then we started recording meetings. 

Then my team started taking AI breaks during meetings (where we each talk to our personal ai systems for 5min to direction check our work and poke holes and give feedback).

Now, we might switch to agent kickoffs for the first 5 minutes so work is happening in the background, then hold the normal meeting, and then automate agent kickoffs when key decisions are made. 

Parallel work can be exhausting. 

Unclear what the best approach is.

items.title:
AI is your ghostwriter, but you are the author.

I was speaking with my friend Arya about the comple...
items.content:
AI is your ghostwriter, but you are the author.

I was speaking with my friend Arya about the complex dynamics software teams face now that most code is being generated by AI agents. There are very few natural bottlenecks to code “slop” - features over quality, and functionality over polish.

I have made a point of banning speaking about AI as the author of code. Codex/Claude didn’t write that code, just like your table saw didn’t cut the wood - you did, with the help of AI. If we start speaking about AI that way, we remove the accountability of the engineer for the quality of the system they are producing.

Arya put it succinctly in a way that I hadn’t heard before: AI is your ghostwriter, but you are the author. It’s your name on the cover of the book.

I think the next year of software engineering will be building out the tools that enable all of us to be proud to sign our name to and take accountability for the increasingly complex systems we produce with our agents.
items.author: @btaylor

Emphasizes that engineers must maintain accountability for AI-generated code quality. Predicts next year will focus on tools enabling code accountability.
items.reasoning: Thoughtful framework for AI-assisted development accountability. Good engagement (252 likes). The 'ghostwriter/author' framing is memorable and practical. Relevant to emerging software engineering culture questions.

items.title:
What's crazy is I just became the "victim" of this without even getting paid for it

A new AI video ...
items.content:
What's crazy is I just became the "victim" of this without even getting paid for it

A new AI video model asked my API provider to promote their new model launching soon

And yes it's a great model and so my APO provider sent me their tweet and I like to talk about new AI models (if they're actually good and this one was) so I quote tweeted it with my take on it and a video of the model

But interesting about is that everyone (including me) posted about that same model on the same day

Obviously it's to hype it up and that's organized

But I don't like those kinds of promotional posts and I definitely don't like to be part of that so I deleted it now

In related news Higgsfield's X account was suspended today for allegedly doing very shady things with X posts on here promising to pay people to RT them but then not paying and other stuff

The AI industry is rampant with these paid promotions and while I'm fine with it, I'd personally prefer to know if it's somebody really posting their opinion or if they're getting paid directly (or indirectly via credits)

The FTC I think already requires people to disclose this for ex with hashtag ad, and I know @X is now heavily enforcing this by suspending accounts that get caught for this, and that's great

Anyway TL;DR just disclose if you're gettng paid to promote stuff, you're legally required to do so anyway!

items.title:
If you are using OpenClaw, do this before it's too late:

Scan every one of your skills using this S...
items.content:
If you are using OpenClaw, do this before it's too late:

Scan every one of your skills using this Skill Scanner. Do not install new skills without first doing this.

This app shows you exactly what skills OpenClaw can access before it runs.

Do not let an AI agent run without understanding what it can do. Remember, these agents have access to your files, your data, and external tools, and they don't ask for permission.

Gen Digital (the Fortune 500 company behind Norton and Avast) is building the "Agent Trust Hub". This is a trust layer for autonomous AI agents.

The OpenClaw Skill Scanner is the first tool they released.

A good analogy is to think about this like a nutrition label for AI skills.

It tells you what the skill can do, what data it reads, and what APIs it can call before you decide to trust it.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago Valdarrama warns about security risks with OpenClaw AI agent skills, recommending Gen Digital's 'Agent Trust Hub' Skill Scanner to audit what AI agents can access before running them. Compares it to nutrition labels for AI.

If you are using OpenClaw, do this before it's too late:

This app shows you exactly what skills OpenClaw can access before it runs.

Do not let an AI agent run without understanding what it can do. Remember, these agents have access to your files, your data, and external tools, and they don't ask for permission.

Gen Digital (the Fortune 500 company behind Norton and Avast) is building the "Agent Trust Hub". This is a trust layer for autonomous AI agents.

The OpenClaw Skill Scanner is the first tool they released.

A good analogy is to think about this like a nutrition label for AI skills.

It tells you what the skill can do, what data it reads, and what APIs it can call before you decide to trust it.

items.content:
So, assuming he doesn't lie for once, let's estimate the number of vibe coders to be around 10 million. This is about 9,999,000 more online app builders compared to when Google was put online.

Google is a result of a PhD. Let's give it 2 years to build. Vibe coding has been around for at least 2 years. So, there's about 10 million new apps. Let assume that 2 out of 1000 are successfull.

Where are 2/100*10,000,000 = 200,000 new googles?

items.title: Parsing PDFs at scale with LLMs is cost prohibitive. Newer models (e.g. gemini 3) are good at readin...
items.content:
Parsing PDFs at scale with LLMs is cost prohibitive. Newer models (e.g. gemini 3) are good at reading pdfs, but you burn unnecessary vision tokens even when the page is text heavy.

We’ve built in a “cost-optimizer” within LlamaParse that will dynamically route pages to fast/cheap parsing depending on its complexity.
Complex pages (e.g. those with tables/charts/diagrams) will still get routed to our VLM-enabled modes.

This will let you save anywhere from 50-90% of parsing costs, at much higher accuracy compared to the comparable mode of feeding screenshots into VLMs.

Check it out! https://t.co/XYZmx5TFz8
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu announces LlamaParse cost-optimizer that dynamically routes PDF pages to cheap vs expensive parsing based on complexity, saving 50-90% of costs vs feeding everything to VLMs like Gemini 3
items.reasoning: Practical, technically substantive product update solving real cost problem in document parsing. High engagement (441 likes). Mentions Gemini 3 capabilities. Addresses key pain point in enterprise AI workflows.
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu announces LlamaParse cost-optimizer that dynamically routes PDF pages to cheap vs expensive parsing based on complexity, saving 50-90% of costs vs feeding everything to VLMs like Gemini 3

We built LobsterX 🦞, an @openclaw specialized for document work on your computer.

It uses high-accu...
items.content:
We built LobsterX 🦞, an @openclaw specialized for document work on your computer.

It uses high-accuracy document parsing, extraction, classification through LlamaCloud, meaning it can comb through complicated PDFs (with scans, tables, diagrams) and extract out 100% accurate context!

It can run as a Telegram bot and is built on top of agentfs (@tursodatabase) as a file system.

Big shoutout to @itsclelia. This is a fun project inspired by @openclaw’s success, and besides being a fun tool to use, it can be a great reference for building your own generalized coding agents!

Readme: https://t.co/ywtmASOoO4
LlamaCloud: https://t.co/qsGFaIL7uM

items.title:
For our free newsletter this week, we talk about the significance of World Models.


@IrenaCronin an...
items.content:
For our free newsletter this week, we talk about the significance of World Models.


@IrenaCronin and I write this newsletter every week.
 
World Models are AI systems that learn how an environment changes over time so an agent can predict what happens next and plan actions, using simulated “what if” futures rather than only reacting. 

This idea shows up in products like World Labs, which targets editable, consistent 3D worlds, Roblox, which is pushing interactive “4D” creation where generated objects behave correctly in games, and Waymo, which uses world modeling to generate controllable driving simulations for safety testing at scale. 

World Models are especially important for robotics because robots face real costs from mistakes, partial sensor views, and complex multi-step tasks, so prediction and simulation can reduce risky trial and error while improving planning and sim to real transfer.

Read for free and subscribe: https://t.co/HHwYy7NoAl

items.title:
'Tis a very odd experience to hear your AI call itself lazy. 

Claude Code made an error, I caught i...
items.content:
'Tis a very odd experience to hear your AI call itself lazy. 

Claude Code made an error, I caught it, I asked why it was wrong, and it told me, "Because I was being lazy about it."

These are the tricky moments of working with AI (knowing where errors can happen, understanding default agent behavior, knowing when to push back) that, unfortunately, make me less hopeful that the late majority will jump on these capabilities.

items.title: LLMs often generate step-by-step instructions, from real-world tasks (how do I file taxes?) to plans...
items.content:
LLMs often generate step-by-step instructions, from real-world tasks (how do I file taxes?) to plans for AI agents. Improving this is hard: outputs can sound fluent for steps that don't work, and current datasets cover few domains. 

How2Everything evals/trains for this at scale. 🧵

items.author: @mattshumer_
items.summary: Matt Shumer explains AI pricing dynamics: frontier model token costs don't drop much, but equivalent intelligence gets much cheaper over time as newer models push the ceiling. Uses an IQ analogy.
items.reasoning: Useful mental model for understanding AI economics from an active AI builder. Good engagement (29 likes, 23K views). Clarifies a common misunderstanding about AI cost trends.
items.summary_html: Matt Shumer explains AI pricing dynamics: frontier model token costs don't drop much, but equivalent intelligence gets much cheaper over time as newer models push the ceiling. Uses an IQ analogy.
items.content_html:
@AHaleIII It's not a simple thing... token costs for frontier models at any given time don't drop much. BUT to get the same level of intelligence, it gets massively cheaper over time.

Dumb analogy: say today's smartest model is "150 IQ" and costs X dollars/token. Next year, "150 IQ" tokens will be way cheaper... but there'll be a new "200 IQ" model available at roughly that same X dollar price point.

So costs are always dropping, just the ceiling keeps rising too.

items.title:
Deploying what you build is what separates a real project from an academic exercise.

I've already b...
items.content:
Deploying what you build is what separates a real project from an academic exercise.

I've already built a couple of dozen agents. Only three of them are in production.

Building the agent is 20% of the work.

Deploying it, keeping it running, handling failures, scaling it, and knowing when it breaks is the other 80%.

Something I've learned the hard way:

Deploying agents is 10x harder than deploying any other software I've built.

• Agents run continuously for minutes or hours
• Agents fail at unpredictable points
• Agents need to retry intelligently, not blindly

Most teams I talk to are duct-taping this together with cron jobs, serverless functions that timeout, and zero visibility into what their agents are actually doing.

This is bad. This backfires every time.

items.content:
The paper actually has two big real points, however:

(1) Humans were bad at prompting (obsolete) AI to get medical advice - I suspect this is no longer as true
(2) Benchmarks of medical knowledge don't always mean reality in serving patients.

1 has changed, I think, 2 has not

items.title: If it is a second opinion to a human (which is what I proposed) then you do not need anything like 1...
items.content:
If it is a second opinion to a human (which is what I proposed) then you do not need anything like 100% accuracy to be helpful. You are looking for potential issues or concerns that someone didn't spot the first time.

And obviously bespoke vendor metrics are not the right ones, use RCTs, etc.

items.content_html:
@liammaniscalco Agreed, and I touch on this a bit in the article. I think the capability will be there very soon, but adoption will take quite a bit longer.

But I still don't think it will be a decade-plus (at least in most industries). There will be a bunch of exceptions though.

No matter what, it's important to be prepared. Even if it takes longer than we expect, I'd rather make sure people are aware than pretend it's not happening

items.title: I think it is reasonable to worry about whether or not people are able to verify AI results. And I d...
items.content:
I think it is reasonable to worry about whether or not people are able to verify AI results. And I don't think RAG is a solution.

So you build the costs of verification into the evaluation and use process for LLMs. In some cases, that is very time consuming, but as a second opinion it is not.
items.author: @emollick.bsky.social
items.summary: Mollick argues RAG isn't a solution to AI verification challenges, and that verification costs should be built into the evaluation and use process for LLMs.
items.reasoning: Interesting practical insight about RAG limitations and verification costs from a credible researcher, though it's a thread reply with minimal engagement.
items.summary_html: Mollick argues RAG isn't a solution to AI verification challenges, and that verification costs should be built into the evaluation and use process for LLMs.
items.content_html:
I think it is reasonable to worry about whether or not people are able to verify AI results. And I don't think RAG is a solution.

So you build the costs of verification into the evaluation and use process for LLMs. In some cases, that is very time consuming, but as a second opinion it is not.

items.title: You should, but the fact is that frontier systems are accurate enough that they are useful as a seco...
items.content:
You should, but the fact is that frontier systems are accurate enough that they are useful as a second opinion. And many people don't have access to experts. This is an empirical question we can measure, if the AI is accurate enough it is a good second opinion

(Not sure what RAG has to do with it?)

items.title: On https://t.co/Qj9rYqJNuu, anyone can make an app. The code of the app is hidden from the user by d...
items.content:
On https://t.co/Qj9rYqJNuu, anyone can make an app. The code of the app is hidden from the user by design, just like the underlying XML of the DOCX is hidden from the user editing a document in Word.

Code in a high-level language is no longer the highest-level abstraction when building software. For most users, it's as low level as binary.

Just as in the past, when only a handful of software engineers coded firmware and drivers in low-level programming languages, only a handful of today's software engineers will code in high-level programming languages.

For this handful of users, on Llambada, there’s a Pro tier. It's the most expensive tier. If you want to code your mini-apps by hand, you will pay more, not less.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov promotes Llambada platform where anyone can make apps without seeing code. Argues code in high-level languages is now as low-level as binary was, with natural language being the new highest abstraction. Charges more for Pro tier users who want to code by hand.
items.reasoning: Provocative thesis about code abstraction levels from the author of 'The Hundred-Page Machine Learning Book'. The idea that hand-coding should cost MORE is contrarian and interesting, though partly self-promotional.
items.summary_html: Burkov promotes Llambada platform where anyone can make apps without seeing code. Argues code in high-level languages is now as low-level as binary was, with natural language being the new highest abstraction. Charges more for Pro tier users who want to code by hand.
items.content_html:
On https://t.co/Qj9rYqJNuu, anyone can make an app. The code of the app is hidden from the user by design, just like the underlying XML of the DOCX is hidden from the user editing a document in Word.

Code in a high-level language is no longer the highest-level abstraction when building software. For most users, it's as low level as binary.

Just as in the past, when only a handful of software engineers coded firmware and drivers in low-level programming languages, only a handful of today's software engineers will code in high-level programming languages.

For this handful of users, on Llambada, there’s a Pro tier. It's the most expensive tier. If you want to code your mini-apps by hand, you will pay more, not less.

items.title:
This is a serious competitor to Lovable and Cursor:

https://t.co/PgVSERT9uG is an AI-powered app bu...
items.content:
This is a serious competitor to Lovable and Cursor:

https://t.co/PgVSERT9uG is an AI-powered app builder:

• Build any app using any stack
• Bring your own API Key to use any model
• Integrates with any database, payments, API

Full flexibility to build whatever you want: web applications, mobile, Chrome extensions, Slack bots, AI agents, etc.

Some really cool features:

1. They have a "Record and Listen" feature where the AI can see your screen and hear your voice. It works like pair programming with a person.

2. You can click on any UI element and describe what you want changed directly. No need to find it in code.

3. Native Supabase and Stripe integrations.

4. No lock-in. You can import projects from anywhere and export your project to other platforms.

5. You only pay what your model costs. No markups.

Really worth checking out.

Thanks to the Orchids team for collaborating with me on this post.

items.content:
Demis Hassabis won the Nobel Prize for AlphaFold. 

Today, his Isomorphic Labs' drug-design system more than doubled AF3 on the hardest cases.

A Demis quote from 2025: "One day maybe we can cure all disease with the help of AI." 

These advances are how the world gets there.

items.title: @rohanpaul_ai There's another thing I'm noticing: the entire speed here on X has sped up. Because AI...
items.content: @rohanpaul_ai There's another thing I'm noticing: the entire speed here on X has sped up. Because AI can create things for you, it creates a competition of some kind where you feel a lot of pressure to get things done, ship things, and post things. It's a unique pressure that I haven't felt earlier in my career.

items.title: This might be the first hot take on how technology tells us how to live our lives, destroying our ab...
items.content:
This might be the first hot take on how technology tells us how to live our lives, destroying our ability to make human decisions.

The technology in question is the sundial.

From a 3rd century BCE Roman adaptation of a Greek play, as discussed in Kerr’s “The Ordered Day”

(It isn't wrong, though)

items.title: It is a useful application of this technology: you should ask frontier LLMs for a second opinion, wh...
items.content:
It is a useful application of this technology: you should ask frontier LLMs for a second opinion, while exercising your own judgement about when to use the answer. It can find gaps so you can follow up on those issues.

But there are many risks and downsides of the technology too, as you say.

Writing tests and letting agents vibe.

items.content:
Which performs better?

Writing tests and letting agents vibe. 
Human writes integration/E2E tests, Agents assist with unit tests under heavy review

You think "obviously human tests perform best"
You ain't seen my tests

@_DaCon it's a great point, but i do think that entire workflows of creating docs + the pdf format itself would need to dramatically change for this to be more "native" 

pdfs represent text for visual display purposes, so to do this today you would need OCR by definition

items.title: 2️⃣ Eval protocol: How2Score measures if a generation contains any critical failures with respect to...
items.content: 2️⃣ Eval protocol: How2Score measures if a generation contains any critical failures with respect to a reference procedure. Frontier LLMs can spot critical failures with high agreement with humans (>80%), and we distill How2Judge, an 8B model that's cheap to run at scale.
items.author: @allen_ai
items.summary: Allen AI describes How2Score evaluation protocol measuring critical failures in generated procedures, with >80% human agreement from frontier LLMs, plus distilled 8B judge model
items.reasoning: Novel evaluation methodology with practical distilled judge model for scalable assessment
items.summary_html: Allen AI describes How2Score evaluation protocol measuring critical failures in generated procedures, with >80% human agreement from frontier LLMs, plus distilled 8B judge model
items.content_html: 2️⃣ Eval protocol: How2Score measures if a generation contains any critical failures with respect to a reference procedure. Frontier LLMs can spot critical failures with high agreement with humans (>80%), and we distill How2Judge, an 8B model that's cheap to run at scale.

items.title: If you are a TypeScript developer, check out Trigger. dev. They are collaborating with me on this po...
items.content:
If you are a TypeScript developer, check out Trigger. dev. They are collaborating with me on this post.

It's an open-source platform for building and deploying AI agents and workflows.

Here is what makes it interesting for anyone running agents in production:

• You can run agents for as long as they need to. No timeouts.
• Automatic retries with fine-grained control.
• You can configure retry logic per task or even per error type.
• Built-in queuing and concurrency controls.
• You decide how many agents run in parallel.
• Full observability. Trace every step of every run.
• You only pay when the code is actually running. No idle costs.

This last point is a huge deal:

Agents spend a lot of their time waiting for tools or human input. Most platforms charge you for that idle time. It gets expensive really quickly!

Here is a link to the platform: https://t.co/Z0A3UUnOtY

items.summary: Santiago promotes Trigger.dev as open-source platform for deploying AI agents with no timeout, auto-retries, queuing, observability, and pay-only-when-running pricing

items.summary_html: Santiago promotes Trigger.dev as open-source platform for deploying AI agents with no timeout, auto-retries, queuing, observability, and pay-only-when-running pricing
items.content_html:
If you are a TypeScript developer, check out Trigger. dev. They are collaborating with me on this post.

It's an open-source platform for building and deploying AI agents and workflows.

Here is what makes it interesting for anyone running agents in production:

• You can run agents for as long as they need to. No timeouts.

• Automatic retries with fine-grained control.

• You can configure retry logic per task or even per error type.

• Built-in queuing and concurrency controls.

• You decide how many agents run in parallel.

• Full observability. Trace every step of every run.

• You only pay when the code is actually running. No idle costs.

This last point is a huge deal:

Agents spend a lot of their time waiting for tools or human input. Most platforms charge you for that idle time. It gets expensive really quickly!

Here is a link to the platform: https://t.co/Z0A3UUnOtY

items.title:
New Release from @PacktDataML — available at https://t.co/fmHgkRo26I

"AI-Native LLM Security — Thre...
items.content:
New Release from @PacktDataML — available at https://t.co/fmHgkRo26I

"AI-Native LLM Security — Threats, Defenses, and Best Practices for Building Safe and Trustworthy AI"

𝘽𝙤𝙤𝙠 𝘿𝙚𝙨𝙘𝙧𝙞𝙥𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣:
"Adversarial AI attacks present a unique set of security challenges, exploiting the very foundation of how AI learns. This book explores these threats in depth, equipping cybersecurity professionals with the tools needed to secure generative AI and LLM applications. Rather than skimming the surface of emerging risks, it focuses on practical strategies, industry standards, and recent research to build a robust defense framework.

Structured around actionable insights, the chapters introduce a secure-by-design methodology, integrating threat modeling and MLSecOps practices to fortify AI systems. You’ll discover how to leverage established taxonomies from OWASP, NIST, and MITRE to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities. Through real-world examples, the book highlights best practices for incorporating security controls into AI development life cycles, covering key areas such as CI/CD, MLOps, and open-access LLMs."
items.author: @KirkDBorne
items.summary: Kirk Borne shares 'AI-Native LLM Security' book covering adversarial AI attacks, threat modeling, MLSecOps, with frameworks from OWASP, NIST, and MITRE.
items.reasoning: Highly relevant topic - LLM security is increasingly important. Book covers practical security frameworks and standards. Good engagement.
items.summary_html: Kirk Borne shares 'AI-Native LLM Security' book covering adversarial AI attacks, threat modeling, MLSecOps, with frameworks from OWASP, NIST, and MITRE.

"Adversarial AI attacks present a unique set of security challenges, exploiting the very foundation of how AI learns. This book explores these threats in depth, equipping cybersecurity professionals with the tools needed to secure generative AI and LLM applications. Rather than skimming the surface of emerging risks, it focuses on practical strategies, industry standards, and recent research to build a robust defense framework.

Structured around actionable insights, the chapters introduce a secure-by-design methodology, integrating threat modeling and MLSecOps practices to fortify AI systems. You’ll discover how to leverage established taxonomies from OWASP, NIST, and MITRE to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities. items.title: Results are that almost 2x more respondents prefer rebuttals. It's a bit surprising. As an X, prefer...
items.content:
Results are that almost 2x more respondents prefer rebuttals. It's a bit surprising. As an X, preferences should be:
- Reviewer, no rebuttals. Less work
- Author, no rebuttals. Less work, and scores increase across papers
- *Researcher*, rebuttals. Ought result in better science https://t.co/qKZQ8OCf9H

items.title: @thomas_dettling This is a timely reminder that AI doesn’t diminish the need for leadership—it raise...
items.content: @thomas_dettling This is a timely reminder that AI doesn’t diminish the need for leadership—it raises the bar for it. Servant leadership feels especially relevant here because human–AI collaboration only works when trust, psychological safety, and learning are intentional. The real leverage isn’t in smarter machines, but in leaders who create the conditions for people to question, grow, and use AI with judgment and care.

items.title:
Build Neo4j-Powered Applications with LLMs

Available at https://t.co/uwuobKTPm3

This LLM book is f...
items.content:
Build Neo4j-Powered Applications with LLMs

Available at https://t.co/uwuobKTPm3

This LLM book is for database developers and data scientists who want to leverage knowledge graphs with Neo4j and its vector search capabilities to build intelligent search and recommendation systems. Working knowledge of Python and Java is essential to follow along. Familiarity with Neo4j, the Cypher query language, and fundamental concepts of databases will come in handy.

𝓦𝓱𝓪𝓽 𝓨𝓸𝓾 𝓦𝓲𝓵𝓵 𝓛𝓮𝓪𝓻𝓷:
🟠Design, populate, and integrate a Neo4j knowledge graph with RAG
🔵Model data for knowledge graphs
🟢Integrate AI-powered search to enhance knowledge exploration
🟠Maintain and monitor your AI search application with Haystack
🔵Use LangChain4j and Spring AI for recommendations and personalization
🟢Seamlessly deploy your applications to Google Cloud Platform

items.title:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how the...
items.content:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how they are shifting because fragmentation is killing performance.

One tool for Automatic Speech Recognition. Another for Text-to-Speech. Another for workflows. Another for analytics.

Every hop adds latency, cost, and failure points.

The future is a single real-time system that listens, reasons, and acts — a shift companies like @elevenlabsio are enabling.

Here is the shift no team can afford to ignore. 

#ElevenlabsPartner
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon

items.summary_html: Ronald van Loon's main thread post about shift from fragmented chatbot stacks to unified voice AI systems, highlighting ElevenLabs as a partner.
items.content_html:
Engineering teams are not shifting from chatbots to voice AI because it is shiny.

I explore how they are shifting because fragmentation is killing performance.

One tool for Automatic Speech Recognition. Another for Text-to-Speech. Another for workflows. Another for analytics.

Every hop adds latency, cost, and failure points.

The future is a single real-time system that listens, reasons, and acts — a shift companies like @elevenlabsio are enabling.

Here is the shift no team can afford to ignore.

items.title:
You will never learn about AI agents by reading blog posts or watching tutorials.

You can only lear...
items.content:
You will never learn about AI agents by reading blog posts or watching tutorials.

You can only learn by building.

Here is a really cool AI challenge.

(Great opportunity to learn and use different AI tools to solve a problem.)

OutSystems is running its Groundhog Day Challenge. They are sponsoring this post.

The challenge is a series of puzzles you can start solving without writing any code.

As you make progress, the challenges become more complex. They force you to build AI agents to crack them.

This is a really good way to learn:

Start simple → Add complexity → Go deeper and deeper

These puzzles are designed for developers of any background to solve.

There's a $1,000 prize, and it runs until February 15th.

Check it out here: https://t.co/NR0eg54Tru

You can see their "Getting started" video here.

items.title: @PAHoyeck @EtienneTRGC It’s actually worse than that. A research study years ago found that, on aver...
items.content: @PAHoyeck @EtienneTRGC It’s actually worse than that. A research study years ago found that, on average, an academic paper is read by less than 2 persons, and that stat included the author and the reviewer. Ouch!! I actually witnessed it in real life. A presenter at a conference (who was a very famous scientist) could not answer an audience member’s persistent questions and finally had to admit that he hadn’t actually read his own paper. He spilled out words on the page, without real attention to it.

items.summary_html: Kirk Borne shares anecdote about academic papers being read by fewer than 2 people on average, and witnessed a famous scientist who hadn't read his own paper
items.content_html: @PAHoyeck @EtienneTRGC It’s actually worse than that. A research study years ago found that, on average, an academic paper is read by less than 2 persons, and that stat included the author and the reviewer. Ouch!! I actually witnessed it in real life. A presenter at a conference (who was a very famous scientist) could not answer an audience member’s persistent questions and finally had to admit that he hadn’t actually read his own paper. He spilled out words on the page, without real attention to it.

items.title:
The biggest surprise for most leaders is how much latency their stack is hiding.

When your AI canno...
items.content:
The biggest surprise for most leaders is how much latency their stack is hiding.

When your AI cannot understand a user for 800 to 1200 ms, the conversation breaks.

With voice native systems like ElevenLabs, Scribe speech to text processes audio in under 150 ms.

That means the agent understands the customer almost instantly.

Instant comprehension changes everything.

You get real dialogue, not call center ping pong.

items.title: Apples to oranges. The area between Shanghai and Beijing is one of the most densely populated areas ...
items.content: Apples to oranges. The area between Shanghai and Beijing is one of the most densely populated areas in the world. Building a dense human rail transport network there makes sense. Furthermore, the US has the biggest rail network in the World, with 140,000 rail miles. Compared to 102,000 miles in China for example. Don’t let outrage grifters get you.

It is such a blessing li...
items.content:
I am not involved but I see a lot of events go by and this one looks good.

It is such a blessing living near San Francisco.

By the way I often can’t afford to go so sneak into the lobby.

I have seen many things first by doing so.

An entrepreneur I had dinner with recently put it this way, cause I asked her if she went to the Sphere.

She said she cooked dinner for her team for a week on what that would cost.

Entrepreneurs hang out in lobbies to meet investors.

@Plinz He is totally aspiring to do all this. 
The constitution and federalism are mild impediments that he hopes to overcome.

The only reason he is not succeeding (yet) is his sheer stupidity and incompetence, and that of his sycophantic cabinet.

He wants to stay in power by all means necessary because otherwise he'll go to prison. 

This is being realistic, not delusional. 
Just any of your European friends.

items.title:
But comprehension is only half the story.
The other half is trust.

Humanlike text to speech gives u...
items.content:
But comprehension is only half the story.
The other half is trust.

Humanlike text to speech gives users the one thing chatbots never could: the feeling that the system actually understands them.

This is where support CSAT jumps, call deflection rises, and customers stay on the line instead of requesting a human.

Natural conversation is simply faster than apps, menus, or forms.

items.title:
wearing a kn95 mask is helping my energy A LOT

my hypothesis: lyme caused me to have immune respons...
items.content:
wearing a kn95 mask is helping my energy A LOT

my hypothesis: lyme caused me to have immune response to particles emitted by common furniture (not just VOC, or else the mask wouldn't work so well)

having organic furniture (e.g. all wood) helps

having strong air filters at home does not help much

anyone else experienced this?

items.summary: Greg Yang shares that wearing a KN95 mask greatly helps his energy, hypothesizing Lyme disease caused immune response to particles from common furniture.

items.title:
It's not just paper

It's thermal paper which is coated with BPA and BPS, endocrine-disrupting chemi...
items.content:
It's not just paper

It's thermal paper which is coated with BPA and BPS, endocrine-disrupting chemicals that are absorbed through your skin

There's more BPA in a single piece of thermal receipt paper than an entire plastic bottle used for years

Repeated exposure to these chemicals are linked to infertility, metabolic dysfunction, and hormonal imbalance

items.summary: Levelsio discusses BPA in thermal receipt paper and its health risks.

items.title: @BillCrosby There is something tangible in seeing these pieces come together, because integration tu...
items.content: @BillCrosby There is something tangible in seeing these pieces come together, because integration turns potential into systems that can actually be tested and stressed. When different technologies start operating as one, progress feels less speculative and more grounded, so the timeline shortens in practical terms. It will be interesting to see how far this coherence can be pushed.

items.title:
@Marty_cFly @AllenBilliams @grok They're completely different

You're comparing radiation risk to ho...
items.content:
@Marty_cFly @AllenBilliams @grok They're completely different

You're comparing radiation risk to hormone disruptors

Radiation at high doses increases cancer risk long term

Hormone disruptors just destroy your hormone regulation potentially causing low testosterone (an epidemic now in men) and other stuff like depression (~15% in many countries now is on anti-depressants) and other behavioral disorders (over 10% of kids in US is on ADHD drugs)

This stuff is not neurotic at all, I think it's good to pay attention to it

Hormone disruptors just destroy your hormone regulation potentially causing low testosterone (an epidemic now in men) and other stuff like depression (~15% in many countries now is on anti-depressants) and other behavioral disorders (over 10% of kids in US is on ADHD drugs)

This stuff is not neurotic at all, I think it's good to pay attention to it

items.title:
@Marty_cFly I don't think really no

Everything in moderation including moderation, but good to avoi...
items.content:
@Marty_cFly I don't think really no

Everything in moderation including moderation, but good to avoid plastics when I can so I do

My T levels are ~800 ng/dl, which is high, my blood work is almost perfect, and I think for a reason because I take care of my health and avoid this stuff

I think it's interesting to see the reaction to this, it feels we're living in two different worlds

Most people now have low testosterone and are overweight, but if you try take care of that by avoiding known hormone disruptors, you're called a neurotic

It's funny

https://t.co/E3tsrzMSYp
